definitions.definition: to fix equipment or furniture into position so that it can be used

examples.text: They're planning to **install a** new drainage **system**.
A hidden **camera** had been **installed** in the room.
A professionally installed alarm will cost from about £500.
An anti-theft device is installed in the vehicle.
The loft ladder is easily installed.
The switches are cheap to buy and easy to install.
They estimate that four out of five child car seats are installed improperly.
Water softening units can be permanently installed into the plumbing system.
The council failed to install pollution-monitoring equipment at the site.

phrases: be installed as CEO, leader, president etc.

definitions.definition: to put a new program onto a computer

examples.text: Do not **download and install** programs from websites that you are unfamiliar with.
Be selective about the apps you install on your device.

phrases: be installed as CEO, leader, president etc.

definitions.definition: to put somebody in a new position of authority, often with an official ceremony

examples.text: He was installed as President last May.
She was recently installed as president of the National Medical Association.

phrases: be installed as CEO, leader, president etc.

definitions.definition: to make somebody/yourself comfortable in a particular place or position

examples.text: We installed ourselves in the front row.
She saw her guests safely installed in their rooms and then went downstairs.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in sense (3)): from medieval Latin installare, from in- ‘into’ + stallum ‘place, stall’. Sense (1) dates from the mid 19th cent.
